meanings.def: the number 1
examples: Do you want one or two?
There's only room for one person.
One more, please!
a one-bedroomed apartment
I'll see you at one (= one o'clock).

meanings.def: used in formal language or for emphasis before hundred, thousand, etc., or before a unit of measurement
examples: It cost one hundred and fifty pounds.
He lost by less than one second.

meanings.def: used for emphasis to mean ‘a single’ or ‘just one’
examples: There's only one thing we can do.
There can only be one winner.
Which do you prefer? The flowery one or the stripy one?
He's just won his 19th singles title.

meanings.def: a person or thing, especially when they are part of a group
examples: One of my friends lives in Brighton.
One place I'd really like to visit is Bali.

meanings.def: used for emphasis to mean ‘the only one’ or ‘the most important one’
examples: He's the one person I can trust.
Her one concern was for the health of her baby.
It's the one thing I can't stand about him.

meanings.def: used when you are talking about a time in the past or the future, without actually saying which one
examples: I saw her one afternoon last week.
One day (= at some time in the future) you'll understand.

meanings.def: the same
examples: They all went off in one direction.

meanings.def: used for emphasis instead of a or an
examples: That was one hell of a game!
She's one snappy dresser.

meanings.def: used with a person’s name to show that the speaker does not know the person
examples: He worked as an assistant to one Mr Ming.

meanings.def: in agreement; all together
examples: We spoke as one on this matter.

meanings.def: to feel that you completely agree with somebody/something, or that you are part of something
examples: a place where you can feel at one with nature

meanings.def: a return to the situation you were in at the beginning of a project, task, etc., because you have made no real progress
examples: If this suggestion isn't accepted, we'll be back to square one.

meanings.def: to be the only person to have a particular opinion or to vote a particular way
used to emphasize that a particular person does something and that you believe other people do too
examples: I, for one, would prefer to postpone the meeting.

meanings.def: to understand or guess something immediately
examples: ‘Oh, so she’s his sister!’ ‘Got it in one!’

meanings.def: to get an advantage over somebody/something
examples: I'm not going to let them get one over on me!

meanings.def: to do something better than somebody else or than you have done before
examples: She did well this year and next year she hopes to go one better.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody/something has different roles, contains different things or is used for different purposes
examples: She's a mother and company director in one.
It's a public relations office, a press office and a private office all in one.

meanings.def: first one person or thing, and then another, and then another, up to any number or amount
examples: The bills kept coming in, one after another.

meanings.def: everyone
examples: Happy New Year to one and all!

meanings.def: used to emphasize that somebody is famous
examples: Here she is, the one and only Rihanna!

meanings.def: used for emphasis to mean ‘the same’
examples: I never realized Ruth Rendell and Barbara Vine were one and the same (= the same person using two different names).

meanings.def: separately and in order
examples: I went through the items on the list one by one.

meanings.def: a few
examples: We've had one or two problems—nothing serious.

meanings.def: having an advantage over somebody
used to say that all types of the things mentioned are very similar
examples: I don't like science fiction novels much. When you've read one, you've read them all.

meanings.def: a very long time ago
examples: I've been going there every summer since the year one.
We spoke as one on this matter.

idioms.def: to feel that you completely agree with somebody/something, or that you are part of something
examples: a place where you can feel at one with nature

idioms.def: a return to the situation you were in at the beginning of a project, task, etc., because you have made no real progress
examples: If this suggestion isn't accepted, we'll be back to square one.

idioms.idiom: be in a minority of one
idioms.def: to be the only person to have a particular opinion or to vote a particular way
used to emphasize that a particular person does something and that you believe other people do too
examples: I, for one, would prefer to postpone the meeting.

idioms.def: to understand or guess something immediately
examples: ‘Oh, so she’s his sister!’ ‘Got it in one!’

idioms.def: to get an advantage over somebody/something
examples: I'm not going to let them get one over on me!

idioms.def: to do something better than somebody else or than you have done before
examples: She did well this year and next year she hopes to go one better.

idioms.def: used to say that somebody/something has different roles, contains different things or is used for different purposes
examples: She's a mother and company director in one.
It's a public relations office, a press office and a private office all in one.

idioms.def: first one person or thing, and then another, and then another, up to any number or amount
examples: The bills kept coming in, one after another.
Happy New Year to one and all!

idioms.def: used to emphasize that somebody is famous
examples: Here she is, the one and only Rihanna!

idioms.def: used for emphasis to mean ‘the same’
examples: I never realized Ruth Rendell and Barbara Vine were one and the same (= the same person using two different names).
I went through the items on the list one by one.
We've had one or two problems—nothing serious.

idioms.idiom: when you’ve seen, heard, etc. one, you’ve seen, heard, etc. them all
idioms.def: used to say that all types of the things mentioned are very similar
examples: I don't like science fiction novels much. When you've read one, you've read them all.
I've been going there every summer since the year one.

meanings.def: used to avoid repeating a noun, when you are referring to somebody/something that has already been mentioned, or that the person you are speaking to knows about
examples: I'd like an ice cream. Are you having one, too?
Our car's always breaking down. But we're getting a new one soon.
She was wearing her new dress, the red one.
Steve's the one with the blue jacket.
My favourite band? Oh, that's a hard one (= a hard question).
What made you choose the one rather than the other?
(British English) How about those ones over there?
There can only be one winner.
Which do you prefer? The flowery one or the stripy one?
He's just won his 19th singles title.
‘Did you get any postcards?’ ‘Yes, I bought four nice ones.’
I bought four ones.
‘Here are the designs. Which (one) do you prefer?’ ‘I think that (one) looks the most original.’
Do you prefer these designs or those?
The Scottish legal system is not the same as the English system
…as the English one.

meanings.def: used when you are identifying the person or thing you are talking about
examples: Our house is the one next to the school.
The students who are most successful are usually the ones who come to all the classes.

meanings.def: a person or thing belonging to a particular group
examples: It's a present for one of my children.
We think of you as one of the family.

meanings.def: a person of the type mentioned
examples: 10 o’clock is too late for the little ones.
He ached to be home with his loved ones.
one to do something She was never one to criticize.

meanings.def: used to mean ‘people in general’ or ‘I’, when the speaker is referring to himself or herself
examples: One should never criticize if one is not sure of one's facts.
One gets the impression that they disapprove.

meanings.def: a person whose behaviour is funny or surprising
examples: Oh, you are a one!

meanings.def: the joke
examples: Have you heard the one about the Englishman, the Irishman and the Scotsman?

meanings.def: to be a person who enjoys something, or who does something often or well
examples: I've never been a great one for fish and chips.

idioms.def: to be a person who enjoys something, or who does something often or well
examples: I've never been a great one for fish and chips.
